bibl.title: Despatches from United States Consuls in Boma, 1888-1895
bibl.publisher: National Archives and Records Service General Services Administration

div1.p:
No 88... US Consulate Goree Dakar March 30th 1886
To the Honorable James D Porter Assitant Secretary of State
Sir, In reply to your request relating to Returns of unofficial fees I have to explain that none whatever have been received at this Consulate sinceit was established and I have not had imporessed on my mind that I ought to have mentioned the fact in some of my Dispatches Begging your pardon for the oversight I shall try and bear in mind that such negative reports are needed in the future.
In this connection it may not be using to that this Consulate cannot be kept and all the regulations

of the Government complied with beyond critism on the meagre salary afforded by "Fees" without pecuniary loss to the incumbent. It is undoubtedly an honor to represent the United States abroad, but if I divine right Consulates in newly-- developed countries when our commerce ought to less expanded do not exist solely for the sake of honoring people, and every hardy prince is not a Didius Luliarners" that he can afford to buy such an expansive luxury.

Pardon me for suggesting that I believe the whole fee septom is one colouslated to weaken the mural would approve of anything to gain the convienance of a consular office on some paint they wished to carry

and have fees for pretended devices multipied almost indefinately is incease his demand against the Government. Seven hunded dollars without fees, and a right to do business, is as small a sum as would support a Consulate here even respectably, and I hope some action will speedily be taken to put it on such a basis.

By employing a clerk for other business enough time might them be given the consulate to have mistakes in conducting its business more generally avoided and reports could them be got up which might be of great value to our citizens. Senegal in a new country with abundant capabilities for supporting a very large commerce it Goree-Dakar with its

excellent commercial telegraphies and model facilities is the commerical centre and will probably soon be the Capital; but of about ten thousand tons of Shipping now in the harder only four hundred are american, and that is much greater than the average proportion: Under such circumstances can it be were for the United States to attempt keeping a compotent Officer here whose salary is insufficient 25 allow him to keep swelle posted on the denial past of his duties.
I am esteemed for Your obident Servant Peter Strickland US Consul
